entry.content:
Okayama Castle is aÂ Japanese castleÂ in the city ofÂ Okayama. In stark contrast to the whiteÂ "Egret Castle"Â of neighboringÂ Himeji, Okayama Castle has a black exterior, earning it the nicknameÂ Crow Castle or "castle of the black bird". (The black castle ofÂ MatsumotoÂ inÂ NaganoÂ is also known as "Crow Castle", but it isÂ karasu-jÅÂ in Japanese.)Â 

The entrance to Tenshukaku is on the first basement floor (B1) of Tenshukaku. After purchasing a ticket, you can take the elevator from the right passage. The way to visit Tenshukaku is to take the elevator to the top floor and then go down one level at a time.

The elevator goes up to the 6th floor, where visitors can see the surrounding area of Okayama Castle. The western side of Okayama Castle faces the "Ujinko Road" and the "Joshita" station, and the southern side of Okayama City Library and Okayama Prefectural Office.

The stairs between floors are not as narrow and steep as those of the original Tenshukaku, but rather wide and gentle, and it is easy to descend from the 6th floor to the 5th floor.

When you look out of the window at the 5th floor, you can still enjoy a good view of the building, especially the shiny "Golden shachi" with gold leaf on the roof.

The nearby Okayama Koraku-en is also a must-see! Â It is one of theÂ Three Great Gardens of Japan, along withÂ Kenroku-enÂ andÂ Kairaku-en. Korakuen was built in 1700 byÂ Ikeda Tsunamasa, lord ofÂ Okayama. The garden reached its modern form in 1863.

After being severely damaged by the bombing of the Second World War, the government restored the park to its original state according to the paintings and designs of the Edo period. It is managed as a historical and cultural asset and will be passed on to future generations.

If you are interested in the historical figures of Japan's Warring States period, you can experience the pride of the Warring States daimyo and the impact of ancient Japanese wars on the rise and fall of generations in Okayama Castle. And the relaxation of Okayama Koraku-en can also be arranged in the same day trip! After the visit, you will feel a sense of physical and mental relaxation.

entry.title: Nara(Kasugataisha Shrine, Todai-ji)
entry.summary: Kasugataisha Shrine is a Shinto shrine in Nara,. It is the shrine of the Fujiwara family, established in 768 CE and rebuilt several times over the centuries. The interior is famous for its many bronze lanterns, as well as the many stone lanterns that lead…
entry.content:
Kasugataisha Shrine is a Shinto shrine in Nara,. It is the shrine of the Fujiwara family, established in 768 CE and rebuilt several times over the centuries. The interior is famous for its many bronze lanterns, as well as the many stone lanterns that lead up the shrine.

Kasugataisha Shrine is a large area and you will see many deer on the way from Nara Park. These deer are very cute and friendly, probably because tourists feed them with "Deer Senbei ".

The "Deer Senbei " are pancakes made of rice bran and flour that visitors can buy to feed the deer. The Nara Park Deer Lovers Association makes this kind of feed for visitors to buy, and the proceeds are used as a fund for the association's operation.

For the purpose of health conservation, the "Deer Senbei " are not seasoned, so they must not have much flavor, but the original fragrance of the rice bran must be very strong.

There are more than 1,000 deer in Nara Park, and the largest number of deer are females! Except for the doe that will be moved to another area in case of a car accident or impending birth, these free little guys in Nara Park are all wild! However, because these deer are wild and may attack people, it is still necessary to pay attention to safety.

"Todai-ji Temple, known for its ""Daibutsu-san,"" or Great Buddha, is a representative temple in Nara, with an imposing appearance of the largest wooden structure in the world. This is a famous temple of the Kegon sect and was founded by Roben.

Todai-ji Temple has a history of 1200 years. During the Nara period, when there were coups and rebellions, Emperor Somu wanted to use the power of Buddhism to relieve social unrest and ordered the construction of Kokubunji and Kokubuniji temples in various countries.

The south gate of Todai-ji Temple (Daikanyinji Gate) is a very imposing wooden structure.You need to buy a ticket to enter Todai-ji Temple, and once you enter, you will see the magnificent Great Buddha Hall, which was registered as a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1998.

Todai-ji Temple is the largest wooden building in the world (47.5 meters high), built as a result of cultural exchange between the Tang Dynasty and China.

Nara City, the oldest capital of Japan and the city with the most domestic world heritage in Japan. It takes an incredible amount of speed to walk the entire World Heritage Site in one day. So it is recommended to spend 2 days, or split into several visits, to appreciate the historical traces carefully.

entry.content:
Himeji CastleÂ is a hilltopÂ Japanese castleÂ complex situated in the city ofÂ Himeji. The castle is regarded as the finest surviving example of prototypical Japanese castle architecture, Â and is frequently known as "White Heron Castle" because of its brilliant white exterior and supposed resemblance to a bird taking flight.

Himeji Castle is very large, covering an area of about 23 hectares, about five times the size of Tokyo Dome. About half of the area has been renovated as a park, and anyone can enter the park for free. The other area, centered around castle tower, requires a fee to enter the city.

Himeji Castle tour focuses on the interior of castle tower, where you can climb to the uppermost floor. There are many information about the history of Himeji Castle, and the miniature model shows the street scene in the past.

Himeji Castle is also a famous cherry blossom viewing spot. When you come to Kansai during the cherry blossom season, Himeji Castle is definitely not to be missed.

entry.title: Hiroshima Peace MemorialÂ
entry.summary: Hiroshima Peace Memorial On August 6, 1945, the U.S. Army bombed Hiroshima with an atomic bomb, and almost all of the buildings near the center of the blast were razed to the ground, except for this building, which barely stood and did not completely collapse.
entry.content:
Hiroshima Peace Memorial

On August 6, 1945, the U.S. Army bombed Hiroshima with an atomic bomb, and almost all of the buildings near the center of the blast were razed to the ground, except for this building, which barely stood and did not completely collapse. The atomic bomb dome was preserved as a memorial of the incident and is part of the Hiroshima Peace Memorial Park.

This building was first completed in 1910 as the â€œHiroshima Prefectural Products Exhibition Hallâ€ and was renamed the â€œHiroshima Prefectural Products Exhibition Hallâ€ in 1921 and the â€œHiroshima Prefectural Industry Award Hallâ€ in 1933, making it an important exhibition venue in Hiroshima at that time.

Hiroshima Peace Memorial Museum

The Hiroshima Peace Memorial Museum is the largest museum in Hiroshima City related to the atomic bombing. The museum details the tragic events of August 6, 1945, and displays artifacts left behind after the atomic bombing so that people can empathize with the victims of Hiroshima.

The power of the atomic bomb was not limited to the many people who died on the spot, but also to the many people who suffered from the effects of the blast, heat injuries, and nuclear radiation. There are many sad stories in the museum, and although I was mentally prepared before visiting the museum, I still feel very strongly after visiting the museum, which makes people cherish the days of world peace.

The Maiko Sea Trail is a trail under the Akashi Kaikyo Bridge, and is similar to the Shikoku-Woji Trail, so you can experience the feeling of â€œwalkingâ€ on the sea.

Walking along the sea trail, you can also see the Sun Moon Memorial Hall (Ijokaku) in the distance, which is built in 1915. Its iconic three-story octagonal hall creates a nostalgic atmosphere.

Finally, when you come to Akashi, you must eat Akashi-yaki, which is similar in appearance to takoyaki but made in a different way.
